head.title: In Kevorkian, Some See a Villain, Some a Hero

hedline.hl1: In Kevorkian, Some See a Villain, Some a Hero

abstract.p: Drs Michael Goldstein and Lidia Shapira letter contends that it is time for Americans to talk more openly about end-of-life issues; says it is disgraceful to suggest that recently televised assisted suicide performed by Dr Jack Kevorkian will to lead to more coherent examination of these complicated legal and moral issues

block.p: Re ''Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide'' (letters, Nov. 29):

As oncologists we agree that it is time for Americans to talk more openly about end-of-life issues. However, it is disgraceful to suggest that the recently televised assisted suicide performed by Dr. Jack Kevorkian will lead to a more coherent and comprehensive examination of these complicated legal, moral and ethical issues.
Re ''Going Beyond Debate Over Assisted Suicide'' (letters, Nov. 29):

As oncologists we agree that it is time for Americans to talk more openly about end-of-life issues. However, it is disgraceful to suggest that the recently televised assisted suicide performed by Dr. Jack Kevorkian will lead to a more coherent and comprehensive examination of these complicated legal, moral and ethical issues.
This country has a large cadre of health care professionals who devote their entire careers to caring for the terminally ill. It is safe to say that Dr. Kevorkian is not one of them.
He has spent his professional career in the field of pathology. Thus his ''patients'' were already dead when he met them.
Dr. Kevorkian has no experience in diagnosing a terminal illness, conveying this to a patient and then caring for the patient through a long and ultimately fatal illness.
To do so requires a skill and compassion that Dr. Kevorkian sadly lacks.
MICHAEL GOLDSTEIN, M.D. LIDIA SHAPIRA, M.D. Brookline, Mass., Nov. 30, 1998
